name: grubber

grubber noun [C]
(TOOL)
Add to word list
Add to word list
a tool for digging up plants: A daisy grubber is specially designed for dealing with troublesome daisies without damaging the lawn. Grubbers are also very useful for breaking up soil.

grubber noun [C]
(SPORT)
sports
  specialized (also grubber kick) in rugby, a forward kick of the ball along the ground: Jon Greene's grubber was crucial in England's win over Australia. St Helens were caught out by Cooke's grubber kick rebounding off their player.
sports
  specialized in cricket, an occasion when the ball is bowled (= thrown to the batter) and does not move up as much as normal when it hits the ground: I was bowled by a grubber. He was fortunate enough to get his bat down in time to stop a grubber.

grubber noun [C]
(PERSON)
informal disapproving someone who tries to get something, usually in a way that is not pleasant or not honest: These are good times for power grubbers trying to gain dominance over others. If you give teachers gifts the day before report cards come out, your child will look like a grade grubber! See also
money-grabber
